section.title: Representing Vectors

introduction.p: A vector can be represented by an arrow of appropriate size and in appropriate direction in the relevant space. For instance, a position vector will be an arrow from the origin to the location of the object in space since prosition is just a displacement from origin to the location in space. You can also represent a vector analytically, i.e., by numbers. One such representation uses Cartesian axes to represent vectors. There are other types of components corresponding to other coordinate systems. We will cover them in due course.

subsection.title: Arrow Representation
subsection.p: Representing vectors and doing mathematics using arrows is the most visual way to get handle on vectors.

subsection.title: Position Vector
subsection.p: Let us begin our studies of vectors by an example position vector (arrow from O to P) of an object at point P in the xy plane of a Cartesian coordinate system whose axes are appropriately tick-marked as shown in Fig. . We will denote the position vector by the symbol \vec r . The (x,y) coordinates of P are (3\text{ m}, 2\text{ m}) .

figure.caption: Illustrating the position vector of an object located at point P. The arrow labeled \vec r represents the position vector - the length of the arrow represents the magnitude and angle \theta can be used to indicate the direction of the vector. Sometimes we call \theta itself the direction of the vector.

subsection.p:
The coordinates x = 3\text{ m}, and y = 2\text{ m} of the tip of the position vector are called x and y components of the position vector \vec r . The magnitude of this vector is the length of the arrow, which can be obtained from x and y.
\text{Magnitude, } r = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2} = \sqrt{13}\text{ m}.
The direction of the vector can be described if we know angle \theta , which we can obtain from x and y also.
\theta = \tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{2}{3} \right) = 33.7^{\circ}.
The direction is then described as: the vector \vec r is in the direction of 33.7^{\circ} counterclockwise from positive x axis.

The angle \theta is not direction. You will get \theta = 33.7^{\circ} for the exactly opposite direction, the direction from origin towards the point (-3\text{ m}, -2\text{ m}). You can check it out. So, once you obtain the angle, you must describe the direction in words!

We now summarize the mathematical relations between the polar-form (r, \theta) and the coordinate-form (x,y) of position vector.
\amp x = r \cos\theta \amp y = r \sin\theta \amp r = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2} \amp \theta = \tan^{-1}\left( \dfrac{y}{x}\right)

subsection.title: The Displacement Vector
subsection.p: Unlike the position vector, displacement vector goest from an arbitrary point A to another point B rather than always going from origin O to some point P.

section.p: Every vector can be drawn the same way as the position vector with length of the arrow representing the magnitude of the vector and the orientation of the arrow representing the direction.

sidebyside.p: The projections of the tip and tail of a vector, \vec A, on the Cartesian axis give us the information from which we obtain Cartesian components of the vector. We denote the components of vectors by attaching letters x or y as subscripts, and the magnitude by the same symbol without the arrow overhead, as shown in the figure to the right.

section.p:
The x-component of the vector, A_x, is difference of the projection of tip and tail on x-axis, and similarly for the y component. The relation between magnitude A, angle \theta, and components A_x and A_y is same as those between r, \theta, and x and y respectively.
\amp A_x = A\, \cos\theta \amp A_y = A\, \sin\theta \amp A = \sqrt{A_x^2 + A_y^2} \amp \theta = \tan^{-1}\left( \dfrac{A_y}{A_x}\right)

For instance, x and y components of a velocity vector \vec v would be represented by symbols v_x and v_y, respectively, and magnitude by symbol v. They are related by
\amp v_x = v\, \cos\theta \amp v_y = v\, \sin\theta \amp v = \sqrt{v_x^2 + v_y^2} \amp \theta = \tan^{-1}\left( \dfrac{v_y}{v_x}\right)

For another property let us look at a force vector, The x and y components of a force vector \vec F would be represented by symbols F_x and F_y, respectively, and magnitude by symbol F. The relations are similar.
\amp F_x = F\, \cos\theta \amp F_y = F\, \sin\theta \amp F = \sqrt{F_x^2 + F_y^2} \amp \theta = \tan^{-1}\left( \dfrac{F_y}{F_x}\right)

example.title: Example of a Force Vector
example.p: For example, if we have a force \vec F , say of magnitude 50\text{ N} in the 30^{\circ} North of East direction, then we will draw an arrow of appropriate size.

p.p: If we use a scale of 1\text{ cm representing } 5\text{ N} , then we will draw a 10\text{ cm}-long arrow, starting at origin and pointing in the direction of 30^{\circ} counteclockwise to the positive x axis where I assume x axis is pointed towards East and y axis is towards North.
This will give the following component form of this force vector F_x = 50\text{ N }\cos\, 30^{\circ} = 43.3 \text{ N} and F_y = 50\text{ N }\sin\, 30^{\circ} = 20\text{ N}.

exercise.title: Magnitude and Direction of a Vector in 2D from Components

statement.p: The position of a box on the floor with respect to a corner of the room, taken to be the origin, and the walls which are taken to be x and y-axes, is given by the (x,y) = (4.0\text{ m}, 3.0\text{ m}). What are the magnitude and direction of the position vector of the box?

answer.p: 5.0\text{ m}, 36.9^{\circ}\text{ or } 0.644 \text{ rad} counterclockwise from +x axis.

solution.p:
Let's do the calculation leaving units out to get the magnitude.
r = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2} = \sqrt{4^2 + 3^2} = 5.
Putting units back, the magnitude of the position vector will be be 5.0\text{ m}.

For the direction, we compute angle \theta with x-axis.
\tan\theta = \dfrac{y}{x} = \dfrac{3}{4} = 0.75.
Inverting this, we get 36.9^{\circ}\text{ or } 0.644 \text{ rad}. Since point (4,3) lies in the first quadrant, the direction is 36.9^{\circ} counterclockwise with respect to the positive x-axis.

exercise.title: Components of a Vector from Magnitude and Direction in 2D

statement.p: A box is at a distance of 5.0 \text{ m} from the origin. The direction of the location of the box makes an angle of 30^{\circ} with respect to the direction of a wall taken to be the positive x axis. Another wall that is perpendicular to the x axis wall is taken to be the y axis. Find the x and y components of the position vector.

solution.p:
Leaving units out, we have
x = r \cos\theta = 5.0 \cos 30^{\circ} = 4.33.
Putting the units back, we get the x = 4.33\text{ m}. Similarly,
y = r \sin\theta = 5.0 \sin 30^{\circ} = 2.50.
With units, y = 2.50\text{ m}.

exercise.title: Components of Velocity Vector of a Cricket Ball in a Horizontal-Vertical Plane

statement.p: A batsman strikes a cricket ball, which leaves the bat with a speed of 20.0\text{ m/s}, and flies in the direction of 60^{\circ} with respect to the horizontal direction. This means that the velocity vector has magnitude 20.0\text{ m/s} and direction 60^{\circ} with respect to the horizontal direction. Taking the horizontal direction as the x-axis and the vertical direction as the y axis, find x and y components of the velocity vector.

solution.p:
Let \vec v be the symbol for the velocity vector, v the magnitude, \theta the angle with x-axis, and v_x and v_y the x and y components of the velocity vector. Doing the calculation leaving units out:
v_x = v \cos\theta = 20.0 \cos 60^{\circ} = 10.0.
Putting the units back, we get the v_x = 10.0\text{ m/s}. Similarly, v_y = v \sin\theta gives v_y = 17.3\text{ m/s}.

exercise.title: Components of Velocity Vector of a Soccer Ball in a Horizontal-Vertical Plane

statement.p: A soccer ball is kicked in the direction 30^{\circ} above the horizontal direction with speed 15 \text{ m/s}. This means that the velocity vector of the ball has magnitude 15 \text{ m/s} and direction 30^{\circ} above the horizon. Find the coordinate representation of the velocity in a coordinate system in which x axis is along horizontal direction and positive y axis is pointed up.

solution.p:
We just use the formulas that help us get components from magnitude and direction.
\amp v_x = v\, \cos\, \theta = 15\text{ m/s}\, \cos\, 30^{\circ} = 13 \text{ m/s}. \amp v_y = v\, \sin\, \theta = 15\text{ m/s}\, \sin\, 30^{\circ} = 7.5 \text{ m/s}.

exercise.title: Magnitude and Direction of Velocity from Components

statement.p: A velocity vector was found to have the following components, v_x = 30.0\text{ m/s} and v_y = 40.0\text{ m/s} with respect to a coordinate system in which x axis is along horizontal direction and positive y axis is pointed up. What are the magnitude and direction of the velocity vector? Describe your direction in words.

answer.p: \left( 50.0\text{ N},\ 53.1^{\circ} \right). The direction is 53.1^{\circ} above the horizon.

solution.p:
Using the defining equations for magnitude (v) and angle (\theta) with x axis we get
\amp v = \sqrt{v_x^2 + v_y^2} = \sqrt{30^2 + 40^2} = 50\text{ m/s}, \amp \theta = \tan^{-1}(v_y/v_x)= \tan^{-1}(40/30) = 53.1^{\circ}.
The angle is in the first quadrant since v_x >0 and v_y>0 . This means that the angle we found is above the horizon.

exercise.title: Magnitude and Direction of Velocity from Components - 2

statement.p: A velocity vector was found to have the following components, v_x = 30.0\text{ m/s} and v_y = -40.0\text{ m/s} with respect to a coordinate system in which the x axis is along horizontal direction and the positive y axis is pointed up. What are the magnitude and direction of the velocity vector? Describe your direction in words.

answer.p: \left( 50.0\text{ N},\ -53.1^{\circ} \right). The direction is 53.1^{\circ} below the horizon.

solution.p:
Using the defining equations for magnitude (v) and angle (\theta) with x axis we get
\amp v = \sqrt{v_x^2 + v_y^2} = \sqrt{30^2 + 40^2} = 50\text{ m/s}, \amp \theta = \tan^{-1}(v_y/v_x)= \tan^{-1}(-40/30) = -53.1^{\circ}.

sidebyside.p: The angle is in the fourth quadrant since v_x \gt 0 and v_y \lt 0 . This means that the angle we found is below the horizon. The arctan value came out negative - which means the angle is clockwise from the x axis as in the figure.

statement.p: A suitcase is draged by applying a force on the strap attached to the suitcase.

sidebyside.p: With respect to a Cartesian coordinate system that has the x axis along the horizontal direction and the y axis vertically up, the components of the force are (F_x, F_y) = (12.0\text{ N}, 5.0\text{ N}) , where N stands for the unit Newton.

statement.p: What are the magnitude and direction of the force? You can use the symbol F for the magnitude and \theta for the angle with respect to the x axis.

solution.p: Let F denote the magnitude of the force, i.e., equivalent of r of the polar form of the vector. F = \sqrt{F_x^2 + F_y^2} = \sqrt{12.0^2 + 5.0^2} = 13.0 Putting the units back, we get the magnitude of the force, F = 13.0\text{ N}.
Leaving units out when doing calculations: \tan\theta = \dfrac{F_y}{F_x} = \dfrac{5.0}{12.0} = 0.42 Inverting this, we get \theta = 22.6^{\circ} \text{ or } 0.395 \text{ rad}.

sidebyside.p: A vector has (A_x, A_y) = (-3, 1) . What is the direction of this vector with respect to the negative x axis?

hint.p: Note arc-tangent will give you a negative angle. You need to appropriately add or subtract 180^{\circ}.

sidebyside.p: The negative sign refers to the clockwise direction into the second quadrant from the negative x axis direction as shown in the figure.
A vector has (A_x, A_y) = (-3, -2) . What is the direction of this vector with respect to the negative x axis?

statement.p: Note arc-tangent will give you a positive angle, which is what you also get if the vector is pointed in the first quadrant. But, this vector is pointed in the third quardant. Therefore, you need to appropriately add or subtract 180^{\circ}.

solution.p:
The angle using the arctangent formula gives the following.
\theta = \tan^{-1} \dfrac{A_y}{A_x} = \tan^{-1}\dfrac{-2}{-3} = 33.7^{\circ}.

sidebyside.p: Based on this calculation, if your answer is 33.7^{\circ}, you would be implying that this angle is counterclockwise with respect to the positive x -axis, but that is wrong since the vector is pointed in the third quadrant, and the angle is with respect to the negative x-axis.

solution.p: If you want to express the counterclockwise angle with respect to positive x-axis, you will need to add 180^\circ to this value.

p.p: A vector has (A_x, A_y) = (3, -2) . What is the direction of this vector with respect to the positive x axis?
Note: the arc-tangent will give you a negative angle.

hint.p: Note that negative angle means clockwise angle.

sidebyside.p:
The angle using the arctangent formula gives the following.
\theta = \tan^{-1} \dfrac{A_y}{A_x} = \tan^{-1}\dfrac{-2}{3} = -33.7^{\circ}.

solution.p: The negative sign refers to the clockwise direction into the fourth quadrant from the positive x axis direction as shown in the figure.

exercise.title: Practice Computing Magnitudes and Stating Directions

statement.p: Clearly, if you have the (x,y) of an object, you can get the position vector by computing the r and \theta .

Draw position vectors of objects at the following coordinates and find their magnitudes and directions.
(-1\text{ m}, 2\text{ m}) ,
(-3\text{ m}, -2\text{ m}) ,
(3\text{ m}, -1\text{ m}) .

answer.p: (a) \sqrt{5}\text{ m}, 63.4^{\circ} clockwise from the negative x axis, (b) \sqrt{13}\text{ m}, 33.7^{\circ} counterclockwise from the negative x axis, (c) \sqrt{10}\text{ m}, 18.3^{\circ} clockwise from the positive x axis.

sidebyside.p:
(a) The drawing is shown in the figure.
\amp r = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2} = \sqrt{1^2 + 2^2} = \sqrt{5}\text{ m}. \amp \theta = \tan^{-1}\left( \dfrac{y}{x}\right) = \tan^{-1}\left( \dfrac{2}{-1}\right) = -63.4^{\circ}.

solution.p: The negative in the angle says that the angle is clockwise from the x axis. Since the (-1, 2) is in the second quadrant, this angle will be with respect to the negative x axis. Therefore, the direction is 63.4^{\circ} clockwise from the negative x axis.
(b) and (c) - do them similarly. Make sure you state the direction as clockwise and counterclockwise from either positive or negative x axis.

exercise.title: Components of a Force Vector from Magnitude and Direction in First Quadrant
exercise.statement:
A force vector \vec F has magnitude 50\text{ N} and is pointed in the direction 30^{\circ} North of East. Let x axis be pointed towards East and y axis towards North. >
(a) Draw a figure to display this vector, stating the scale you used in your drawing.
(b) Find the x and y components, F_x and F_y , of this vector.

hint.p: The (F_x, F_y) have the same relation to (F, \theta) as do (x,y) to (r, \theta) .

p.p:
(b) The (F_x, F_y) have the same relation to (F, \theta) as do (x,y) to (r, \theta) .
\amp F_x = 50\times \cos\, 30^{\circ} = 43.3\text{ N}. \amp F_y = 50\times \sin\, 30^{\circ} = 25.0\text{ N}.

exercise.title: Components of a Force Vector from Magnitude and Direction in the Fourth Quadrant

statement.p: A force vector \vec F has magnitude 50 N and is pointed in the direction 30^{\circ} South of East. Let x axis be pointed towards East and y axis towards North.
(a) Draw a figure to display this vector, stating the scale you used in your drawing.
(b) Find the x and y components, F_x and F_y , of this vector.

hint.p: The (F_x, F_y) have the same relation to (F, \theta) as do (x,y) to (r, \theta) . Be mindful the quadrant and take care of signs of components accordingly.

solution.p: (b) The (F_x, F_y) have the same relation to (F, \theta) as do (x,y) to (r, \theta) .
When you have a vector in a quadrant other than the first quadrant, you need to make sure you take care of the sign of resulting components by observing where the vector projects on the axes.

sidebyside.p:
Here, since the vector is in the fourth quadrant, it will project on the positive x and on the negative y. That will mean F_x \gt 0 and F_y \lt 0.
\amp F_x = 50\times \cos\, 30^{\circ} = 43.3\text{ N}. \amp F_y = -50\times \sin\, 30^{\circ} = -25.0\text{ N}.

exercise.title: Magnitude and Direction of a Force Vector from Components in the Second Quadrant

statement.p: The x and y components of a force vector are given to be F_x = -30\text{ N} and F_x = 40\text{ N}. What are the magnitude and direction of this force?

hint.p: use (x,y) to (r, \theta) and interpret the angle.

answer.p: F = 50\text{ N}, 53.1^{\circ} clockwise from the negative x axis

solution.p:
The magnitude is
F = \sqrt{30^2 + 40^2} = 50\text{ N}.
Since the point ( -30, 40) is in the second quadrant, we will get angle with respect to the negative x axis.
\theta = \tan^{-1}\left( \dfrac{40}{-30}\right) = -53.1^{\circ}.
The negative angle means we need to go clockwise. Thus, the direction is 53.1^{\circ} clockwise from the negative x axis.
